items.title: Op deze zender kijk je zondag naar Afrika Cup-finale Senegal tegen Marokko

items.title: Keane snapt niets van Man Utd-terugkeer Evans: 'Allemaal een week naar Barbados'

items.title: Football Daily | Windmilling prize fighters show their class in League Cup semi-finals
items.summary: Sign up now! Sign up now! Sign up now? Sign up now! Milk. Littlewoods. Rumbelows. Coca-Cola. Worthington‚Äôs. Carling. Capital One. Carabao. No matter which name is above the door, the League Cup has maintained certain traditions and idiosyncrasies, including those two-legged semi-finals. The exploits of fourth-tier Bradford City aside, these double-headers tend not to linger in the collective memory, being neither as high profile as Bigger Cup‚Äôs final four, nor as singular as the one-off FA Cup semis. Still, we have to respect the Football League‚Äôs grind here ‚Äì it has managed to keep this format quirk in place for England‚Äôs third biggest trophy while the global football calendar destroys itself. Its trump card: asking the Premier League for some extra pennies to scrap the second leg. And so, we continue. I have an issue with the Football Daily newsletter‚Äôs tone. I feel like you try to insert so many jokes/snarky comments or choose certain words that make it come across to me as a bit unserious, such as yesterday‚Äôs edition. I‚Äôm mostly able to ignore this and won‚Äôt unsubscribe because of it, but consider toning it down or change the name of the newsletter to what it really is: Football Daily (with jokes)‚Äú ‚Äì Kachilapo Mulongoti. Uefa shutting out Mariana Cabral because she lacks the ‚Äòright‚Äô Pro Licence (yesterday‚Äôs Quote of the Day) feels about as modern as a fax machine in a village post office, and just as transparent as the old circus that nearly punched boxing into irrelevance. It‚Äôs the same weary routine: dress up gatekeeping as ‚Äòstandards‚Äô, funnel opportunity toward the same old boys‚Äô network, and feign surprise when people spot the unmistakable whiff of favouritism. Cabral‚Äôs experience simply confirms what fans have muttered for years: Fifa and Uefa aren‚Äôt stewards of the game, they‚Äôre heritage institutions propped up by ego, nostalgia, and a financial ecosystem held together with tape and hypocrisy‚Äù ‚Äì Harry Webb. Congratulations to Max Ibrahimovic on his move to Ajax (yesterday‚Äôs News, Bits and Bobs, full email edition). Unrelatedly, I wonder if his dad ever regretted helping pick the name ‚ÄòMax Ibrahimovic‚Äô for his son, rather than a line of fragrances, athlete‚Äôs foot creams and/or personal massagers?‚Äù ‚Äì Rowan Sweeney. Your story about Swindon manager Ian Holloway‚Äôs distaste for modern communication methods can‚Äôt be right (yesterday‚Äôs Football Daily, full email edition). His recent defence of Ollie Clarke‚Äôs conduct suggests he is all in favour of digital interventions, does it not?‚Äù ‚Äì Dale Sellers. This is an extract from our daily football email ‚Ä¶ Football Daily. To get the full version, just visit this page and follow the instructions. Continue reading...

items.title: Harbaugh agrees to become Giants head coach
items.summary: John Harbaugh has agreed to become the new head coach of the New York Giants, with the former Baltimore Ravens leader finalising a five-year deal with the four-time Super Bowl champions.

items.title: Spurs bring Heitinga on to Frank‚Äôs staff and make Moersen director of football operations
items.summary: Heitinga to have big role with defence, Frank says Moersen to serve months of gardening leave Tottenham have appointed John Heitinga, the former Ajax head coach and assistant to Arne Slot at Liverpool, to Thomas Frank‚Äôs coaching staff. Frank said one of the Dutchman‚Äôs main responsibilities would be to work with the defence. Heitinga‚Äôs arrival was confirmed after Spurs announced that Carlos Raphael Moersen was joining as their first director of football operations. He is coming in from City Football Group, which oversees a stable of clubs that includes Manchester City. Continue reading...
